Problem Overview

In this Problem, students investigate a spinner that Kaleb might use to determine his bedtime. Students confront some possible misconceptions about the relationship between angle measure and probability situations involving spinners.

Mathematical Note: The spinners in this Problem are circles with the spinning mechanism in the center of the circle. Because of the shape, the ratio of the angle measures and/or the ratio of the areas of a sections can be used to determine the theoretical probability. Students may accurately use either area or angle measure.

In contrast, on a spinner like the one below, the spinning mechanism is not in the center of the circle.

In this example, the ratio of the angle measures can be used to determine the theoretical probability. The ratio of the areas of the sections cannot be used to determine the theoretical probability. Red and blue are equally likely, but it does not appear that way because the area of the sections is very different.

Emerging Mathematical Ideas

Build on experiences with theoretical probability by adding a new tool and examining a compound event:

Notice that:

  • A compound event is a game that consists of two events
  • Organized lists and tree diagrams can be used to find the possible outcomes for compound events
  • A spinner can be used to determine experimental probability. The area of the spinner is subdivided to represent each event.
  • Using the results of experimental trials, you can predict future outcomes

To find theoretical probability with a spinner you would have to determine the portion of the area of the spinner to determine how likely a result might be.
